Award.AwardTitle: Postdoctoral Research Fellowship: Exploring the Initial Rise of Urbanization in an Ancient Preclassic Society

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Award.AbstractNarration:
SBE Postdoctoral Research Fellow Santiago Juarez's archaeological research (under the mentorship of PI Palka) is relevant to the analyses of complex societies. This project investigates how the actions and activities of members of an ancient community influenced the construction of an early urban society during the Preclassic (2500 B.C.-A.D. 200) period at a recently discovered Maya site in Chiapas, Mexico. During each field season, Juarez and other project members present their latest findings through conference style papers (which include illustrations, figures, and reconstructions) during community gatherings. Additionally, this project integrates students from the University of Illinois at Chicago during the survey, excavation and laboratory phases. Broadening participation of a diverse group of people in the scientific workforce is one the stated goals of this project; as such, the research provides an opportunity to train students in archaeological methods to develop relevant experience and provides undergraduates with data for theses. Both the PI (Palka) and Fellow (Juarez) have demonstrated a strong commitment to increasing the participation of minority students in scientific research. In this project, students not only receive hands-on training in archaeological research methods, especially in skills such as mapping and GIS technology that are in high demand, but also in developing their own research projects.

By focusing on models of social organization, this research explores the relationships and interactions that sustained this ancient community during a period of massive growth and change. This project is expected to reconstruct how people of all levels were involved in the urban formation processes; results of this work could add new depth to the study of state-formation and the rise of civilization by focusing on the social and economic practices of all residents of a community. Military force, royal marriage alliances, and diplomacy are often seen as key catalysts in the development of Preclassic Maya urbanization; although such processes were indeed important in the expansion of ancient communities, Juarez proposes that the actions of common people played an equally important role in the growth and expansion of trade networks and economies. Overall, this project provides a holistic understanding of one of the earliest urban societies in the Americas. Ultimately, such knowledge not only advances the field of archaeology but also contributes to understanding, protecting, and celebrating our rich and diverse cultural heritage.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

                The latest findings at the Maya site of Noh K’uh have both expanded both the history of the site, and our understanding of early urban organization during the Maya Preclassic (2000 B.C- A.D. 250).  This research project has placed special emphasis on the investigation of the ancient remains of commoners; the regular people of the ancient world.  My findings stem from a growing body of research that attempts to understand the initial rise of cities in the Maya area by focusing on the majority of the population, as monuments and hieroglyphic texts only focused on religious activities and the actions of rulers.   The latest discoveries at Noh K’uh reveal that commoners were not passive peasants, but were in fact directly involved in the physical construction of their urban landscape.  Beginning with individual homes, my findings revealed that homes had a deep history, dating back to a period between 800 and 400 B.C., a time when the first generation of cities emerged in the Maya region.   My findings further reveal that domestic spaces were the result of significant labor investment that resulted in a reshaping of the broader landscape.  Ultimately, the entire population appears to have worked together during the initial rise of urbanism; investments into individual households and the broader community were essentially linked.

                The most recent excavations also provided the first opportunity to compare findings from domestic spaces with materials from the urban core.  Commoner constructions represented significant labor investments, but they still managed to use materials and resources that existed within the immediate vicinity of ancient habitations.   Clay, stone, sand, and plaster were the typical components of a domestic architecture.   The architecture near the core of Noh K’uh represented a completely different level of investment, as the entire 125 x 125 meter platform appears to have been constructed out of stone boulders and a thick plaster lining.  While the stone in domestic buildings could be found virtually anywhere on natural surfaces and rivers, the boulders used to create the ceremonial core had to be quarried from a limestone outcrop.   Such intensive labor investments indicate that this space was not an expansion of daily activities, and represented something completely different.   The construction of the core was intentionally designed to be grander in both scale and design.   Furthermore, current excavation evidence suggests that the spaces did not serve as living spaces, but were instead reserved for specific events, possibly public gatherings.  

                Thus far, findings from Noh K’uh suggests urbanism was a fast paced and intensive process when it first arrived in this valley.   Hills were flattened, new mountains were built from stone, and the physical space was reshaped to create the small city of Noh K’uh.  More importantly, no one played as passive role in this process, as the whole community was responsible for reshaping the local landscape.   This challenges explanations that favor the action of social hierarchs as the drivers of burgeoning urbanization.  

Broader Impact

 

At the local community level, the relationship between archaeological research and the town of Mensabak continues to strengthen and develop.   In previous field seasons, we have directly reported our findings to both community leadership and the broader community in the form of town hall gatherings and written reports.   During my postdoctoral fellowship, I developed visual displays that provided a permanent means of communicating our finds to the general public (Figure 1).  Using artistic reconstructions I created along with site descriptions modeled from the reports developed by project colleagues, I created general portraits of how sites appeared in the ancient past.   This not only allowed me to clearly discuss our findings, but it provided the community of Mensabak with physical materials to present to tourists who frequently visit the area.   The presentation of such materials was so successful, that the community has asked for more of this material, particularly in pamphlet form, so that the information can be shared with outsiders. 

I am also pleased to report an unexpected impact, specifically in regards to local gender roles.  To be clear, I am not the first researcher to hire women for archaeological investigation at Mensabak, nor was I the first to train them in methods.   I was however the first to assign a woman to a position of authority, as a supervisor.   I was unaware that by giving this woman more authority and independence, that it would represent a significant event to local women.   As several Lacandon women explained to me, I had essentially “hired a woman for a man’s job”.   The women of Mensabak are using events such as these to argue for a greater role in the community’s economy.  While there is still resistance, women of the community are now creating their own businesses with the goal of fueling the town’s burgeoning tourist industry.
